review_title: I've been at Square for more than three years.
pros:
Square has been a great place to work for the past few years. It's provided me the opportunity to grow in my career and learn new skills, while simultaneously witnessing a rapidly growing company adjust on the fly to new challenges.

Working at a company that grows and changes so rapidly has been one of the best ways to learn quickly. The amount of experiences that I feel like I've faced in the few years I've been here seems much higher than my peers at slower moving companies. I think this can only benefit me.

There are a lot of great people here to work with and learn from. I have real friends here, not just co-workers.

Leadership has become much stronger on account of some key hires.
cons: Growing pains come with the territory when you move quickly in an industry that is constantly changing. We are going up against behemoths that have deeper pockets and more resources than us. In my opinion, that makes it a bit more fun, but it does make for some thrash as the priorities evolve and shift with the changes in the environment.
advice_to_mgmt: Maintain transparency.

pros: Great people, culture and interesting challenges.

pros:
- The engineers here tend to be really good. The senior engineers are the best and brightest I've worked with. The junior ones are also very sharp and have lots of potential.
- Some really interesting technical problems to work on -- lots of fun, challenging, and interesting work.
- In addition to being smart, the people are generally great to get along with.
- Cash compensation is good for this market. Benefits are decent. And equity has a chance to be worth a lot.
- Transparency and meritocracy are strong values (much better than typical corporate culture).

- Cool office space (SF has amazing space, a shuffleboard table, and a pool table. ATL has a cool space, nice bar, and a ping-pong table.)
cons:
- We're not yet great at remote collaboration (video conferencing, etc). This can make it hard, being outside of SF (though things have been constantly improving since I've been here -- it was really bad when I first started).
- Sometimes there are techno-politics to deal with. Engineers are diverse in opinions (which is great!). But there seem to be a lot of ideologists and fewer pragmatists (not great!)
- Roller coaster ride based on press coverage. (It's been more negative press recently I think, which is saddening, especially since so much of it is inaccurate.)

pros: I feel so lucky to work here. My team is full of incredibly smart, friendly, funny people - all people I'd want to be friends with outside of work. I feel both challenged and supported in my work. I genuinely trust Jack as a leader as well as the rest of our execs. And of course the perks and office space are wonderful too. Pay feels really fair, even generous (except for holiday time: see below.)

However, I think that if you're going to require people to stay and work over holidays, you should be paying them enough them enough to really make it worth it.
advice_to_mgmt: Incentivize holiday time off such that, instead of forcing people to stay, they actually WANT to. This is better for everyone in the long run.

Whether you want to focus on one area or contribute to project across the board, Square is a great place to work! My peers are amazingly talented. I think I have a good work-life balance.

We also have a culture of pair-coding, which I think is great. It prevents procrastination, encourages the exchange of skills, and helps ensure more than one person is really familiar with the codebase.

You can read more about Square Engineering: http://corner.squareup.com
cons: Square is still a rapidly growing company which comes with pros and cons.

review_title: Great company, poor organizational structure, lacking quality leadership
pros:
I love working for Square, the company. The work I do goes directly to our customers and helps them build their business. When I see or meet Square sellers out in the world, I'm motivated and inspired to continue the work I do at Square.
Additionally, Jack's leadership is inspiring. I trust him to have clear intention for the business, but also care what's happening inside the company. I feel like I can approach him and question how decisions were made, or why we do things the way we do.
cons: The sub-levels of leadership are awful. Some orgs are run with no care for the employees, but rather driven by data. Some orgs are managed haphazardly, and with no transparency whatsoever. Managers are leading groups of people, without knowledge or understanding of the work they ask their employees to do on a day-to-day basis. This has led to zero trust and high levels of frustration. How can one be considered successful in the eyes of a manager with no context for success? My boss only "knows" I'm doing well when he hears it from others, but does not seek it out, nor give me the benefit of the doubt when approached with feedback.
advice_to_mgmt: Make the hard decisions, cut the fat and get rid of the people who are more problematic than they are valuable. Seek out and ask what the teams at the "bottom" really need, and give it to them. The attrition and thrash will stop when we have fewer political problems, and more permission to make decisions and therefore, work.

review_title: Greatest company I've ever worked for, I'm surrounded by the smartest people.
pros:
The transparency and trust culture at Square is one in a million.

We hire amazing people. Sometimes we hire great people into the wrong role, and always people outgrow and develop beyond the responsibilities outlined on their first day. What's amazing about Square is the ability and encouragement to grow and redefine our roles as well as move beyond them into other opportunities within the company!

The people I work for and with are extremely inspiring and intelligent. I have extremely faith in our drive forward into the future!
cons:
We work fast, which I would argue is a pro, but I've seen individuals struggle when not passionate about their work.

Compensation bumps have been moved to once a year to seemingly make it easier on finance projections, but I don't feel like people grow in their roles at the same cadence around the same date of the year.
advice_to_mgmt: From outside the executive team looking in it seems that Jack wants to let his leadership team work out problems among each other alone, but from time to time I think he could step in more.

pros: I work at Square because we have a purpose, a goal, something to believe in.

pros: There is an extremely high bar for hiring so everyone you work with is extremely intelligent and fun to be around, making you want to come to work every day. I have awesome work life balance - management is concerned about the quality of my work, not the number of hours I'm in the office. The office is beautiful and the perks are great as well!

The people are top notch and it's impossible not to learn while working with such talented people across many disciplines. The culture is super open, transparent and collaborative. It's really easy to reach across what would at other companies be barriers to get things done. The food is also amazing, which doesn't hurt!
cons: The fast growth and dynamism can sometimes feel like churn. There's so much going on it's sometimes hard to keep track of all the projects that are being worked on.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work! Let's keep crushing our goals.

pros:
Motivation and hard work that is evident throughout the office
Management team is superb
Transparency
Amazing Food
Always Learning
cons:
Negative Press can hinder outside outlook
Young company and cannot spread into various industries too quickly
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to stay transparent about the direction of the company

review_title: Square will challenge you everyday, and you will love it.
pros:
- The work you do is challenging. Many times, the work you take on is something no one else has ever tackled. Whether you deploy a new service or close a new deal, the work that we do here is very rewarding, and many times there is enough visibility within the company where your work will be noticed by many.
- It doesn't matter if you're a new employee, employee number 40, or an intern. Everyone has a chance to make a huge impact, and Square enables employees to do so.
- The majority of co-workers are former Googlers, Facebookers, etc. They have many experiences and are willing to share their knowledge to anyone at Square. I can't imagine a better place to sharpen my engineering skills as a new grad in the industry.
- The hiring bar is structured such that most of the people at Square are not only smart, but they are also personable and social. This makes a great working environment, and the company outings are something to look forward to.
- Benefits are amazing (e.g. unlimited vacation, free meals).
cons:
- Deadlines for key projects are sometimes aggressive.
- We are growing extremely fast.

pros:
It is very fun to work for such a startup company. Even though the company grows over 1000+ employee now, you still have lots of chances to make the impacts as an individual. There are also lots of bottom-up ideas become company's strategies.

It will be hard to imaging about the company's transparency until you joined. It is a fantastic culture.

One last thing i wish to highlight is the Food~ Compared with lots of free cafeteria among those bay area companies, Square's food is super good~!
cons: Growth too fast is a pain, even the managers in Square are still learning and growing.

review_title: Square is a fantastic company with an aggressive roadmap for growth
pros: The products are world-class, the brand is well-known, design is a first-class citizen and there is a lot of room for growth both as a company and an individual
cons: I think we're really going through growing pains right now, there have been so many people added to the company in a short period of time that there is a lot of chaos and sometimes overlapping efforts from team to team. Leadership has definitely identified this and is doing a good job aligning efforts at a global level

review_title: Square is best company I've worked for
pros: You work with really smart individuals on problems that help people grow what they love doing.
cons: Salary is a little low, but the potential is huge!

pros:
- The work is extremely rewarding. Every project makes a meaningful impact on your peers and millions of merchants.
- Competitive compensation. Great benefits.
- Project autonomy
cons: You need to make a conscious effort to maintain a work-life balance. In a previous life, I worked at Google and my day ended at 4:30pm. At Square, I regularly work 10 hours... not because it's required, but because I'm passionate about my projects. Perhaps our micro kitchens are stocked with too much Kool-Aid?

pros: The perks are great (benefits, food, office), but my favorite part of working at Square are my co-workers. I've learned so much in the past year because pretty much everyone I work with is either really experienced or very eager to learn.
cons: The compensation and benefits aren't as great as larger companies in the bay area (eg: Google, Apple)
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work, and continue making commerce easy!

review_title: Vibrant workplace, smart colleagues, great opportunities.
pros: Rewarding work, deep technical problems to solve which have direct impact to the business. Culture of openness and collaboration; company structure treats employees with respect and rewards individual responsibility and initiative. Unbeatable time off and leave policy.
cons: Can be intense at times; there's a lot of work to be done. Company experiments with improving internal process regularly and is growing rapidly, which can lead to some heartburn as management adjusts. Career growth is very self-driven. No 401k match.

pros: Square is surprisingly meritocratic for a company this size and growth trajectory. There are tons of smart people around who recognize good work and nurture it. Effectively, if you come to Square, you'll learn a lot, and if you work hard, you'll be recognized and your ideas will make it out into the world.
cons: Super flat hierarchy means that you've to seek out non-traditional ways of "climbing the ladder". Some people find it a bit all-encompassing. Some workaholism is found :)
advice_to_mgmt: Get even better at recognizing good work. Not everyone has the scrappiness to self-promote, and not everyone should (the organization doesn't function is everyone is self-promoting). Strive for objectivity in prioritizing both work and people.

review_title: Quality treatment of employees; Quality production of work
pros: I'm starting on my third week as a full-time Square employee, and I could go on about the quality of treatment as an employee here. The environment, colleagues, resources, technology are brilliant, and I go to work every day feeling valued. The access to resources and equipment is impeccable, and any troubleshooting or questions needing to be answered are met with friendly responses from co-workers who are eager to help. Work-Life balance is perfect, mainly because I don't dread coming to work. The company itself values transparency, which is something I highly respect. There isn't a tier-to-tier block when wanting to know whats going on. The leaders I respond to see you eye-to-eye, and don't look down on you from a pedestal. I don't see myself going anywhere for quite some time.
cons: I guess the only concern I have (although it's something I haven't much thought of or brought up to my manager) is personal growth within the company. During orientation, the progression of different roles was unclear; but honestly, this isn't too big of a concern of mine. The company is growing exponentially, and judging by the treatment of its employees, I would guess the same of internal advancement.
advice_to_mgmt: Perhaps a little more time spent on orientation. 3 days wasn't enough to fully grasp the company in-and-out.

review_title: My work significantly impacts the company
pros:
Square is an awesome place to work right now. The company is still small enough that my work has a major impact on the company, but large enough to provide great benefits and job security. Teams from all different disciplines (engineering, marketing, support, legal, management) work together so well and help each other succeed. Upper management is incredible. They're very open and honest, and nobody is off limits if you have a question.

The Atlanta office has a great group of engineers. It has a small company vibe, but we're very connected with SF and work with teams their daily.
cons: Working on impactful projects can be demanding. Square is growing in a competitive market, and people naturally feel pressure to implement high-quality new features within a tight timeframe.

pros: I've been at Square for 15 months, and it's the most impactful role I've ever had. The company has a mission that's energizing and makes me want to come in to work every day. Our customers love our products and service, and we have a NPS score that's unreal. The culture is one of extreme transparency, which is amazing. Commerce, the space we play in, is massive and we have an opportunity to be the leader here.
cons: Employees are very smart but also very young (for many, it's their first job) and so they tend to take media report of Square too seriously. I wish I could get on a bullhorn and tell them that media doesn't matter. What matters is the value you are creating for customers and stakeholders. So let's just focus on that and not get distracted by the constant chatter outside.

review_title: Great mission, great products, great work environment
pros: I haven't been here long, but everything I've experienced at the company has been positive so far. Everyone I've spoken to from Jack down to my peers is super intelligent and motivated. The products are meaningful and built so that anyone can understand and use them, even people who aren't on the cutting edge of technology. And the office is gorgeous and stacked with perks and amenities.
cons: Square feels like a little fish in a big pond with bigger companies tackling the same problems, but it feels like our size can be an advantage when it comes to moving quickly and innovating.
advice_to_mgmt: Please continue the culture of transparency as much as possible!

review_title: More smart people in one company than I've ever worked with
pros: Square engineers are smart, motivated, and flexible. We get to work with a variety of technologies (for those who want to, at least), and there are always new things going on (technologically, business-wise, geographically). Square is innovating in a variety of ways to make things easier for our customers. It is a collaborative environment so it might be a better fit if you enjoy working closely with other people than if you prefer to sequester yourself with a problem and solve it on your own.
cons: Although the general management and prioritization situation has gotten better with a few really good executive hires, there are still things which fall through the cracks given shifting priorities (which up to a point is desirable), re-orgs, and an emphasis on building new things (keeping existing things running does happen, but isn't planned for by management in the same way).
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on the tier of management between the executives and the individual contributors. Many of these people are promoted from individual contributor roles (at least in engineering), which is not a problem, but do focus on what these frontline managers need to be successful (skills, organizational support, good ways of making decisions with each other and higher-ups, etc). Attract and cultivate managers who can do this job as well as we do for individual contributor and executive roles.

review_title: No such thing as dreaded Sunday evenings
pros:
I go to bed every night, excited to go to work the following morning. I occasionally find myself on the verge of tears (of joy) when company accomplishments are shared and celebrated. The executives and managers are accessible and openly share information. The transparency that seems to be the theme of every review is REAL, and is a concept I never really understood until I joined Square and realized how much information is shared.

I love being in a challenging environment, and everyone is smart and passionate about our work as a company. I've never experienced such personal connection with previous employers, and I love working at a place where we all truly believe in our work, and share the goal of making commerce easy for everyone.

And of course, a review wouldn't be complete without mentioning perks. Excellent health benefits, wellness services on-site, culinary staff, etc.
cons:
There isn't much mobility to work across teams/products for non-engineers, and growth opportunity is unclear.

We've also been victims of bad press lately, which is frustrating. However, I feel like everyone does a great job re-focusing on our missions, strengths and weaknesses during our company-wide meetings on Fridays.
advice_to_mgmt: More flexibility/opportunities for employees to work across teams. Some teams aren't afforded the luxury of participating in collaborations (e.g. Hack Week), due to daily obligations and deadlines.

review_title: Great place to learn and work
pros: This company is still fairly new so we all are learning and challenging each other. We success together and fail together as a team. People here are smart, young, and energetic. Very transparency company that we share all information within all teams.
cons: The company been growing very fast and start to lose connection with people and might lose focus on the key thing. As the company continues to grow faster and bigger, it getting less opportunity to try different things and get your voice out.

pros: The culture is very inclusive and open. Everybody is onboard and excited to build on Square's growth every day. I am learning new things all time for excellent/bright peers.
cons: Since its large growth, its probably taking longer than it could do for top-level decisions to permeate to the ground team! Its hard here to have the urge to take time off!

review_title: Work With Smart People and Better the World
pros:
Really energetic and vibrant company with really well rounded and talented peers. It's fascinating to work at a company that has tripled in size since I joined and has a lot of really cool products on the road map. We bolster businesses in a really positive way and receive encouraging feedback from our customers.

Offices are a little sterile, but very nice. Great benefits and perks (especially if you like coffee, smoothies or free food).

Transparency is excellent. It's refreshing to know what our finances look like, what's on the product roadmap and why decisions are made. It helps promote accountability and gives me the information I need to do my job.

The product leadership is great -- we set ambitious hardware and software goals and generally get things out close to deadline.
cons: Career advancement is a bit difficult. The company structure is very flat, so if you want to lead a team someday, odds are that's not going to happen. However, if you have an idea or something you think the company should be doing, you can add it to your role and put together a project team to help you. It's just hard to ever get to a I-Have-Direct-Reports position if you aren't hired directly into one.
advice_to_mgmt: Consider promoting from within when leadership roles open up rather than always asking "Who's the best external person in the world for this job?"

review_title: Even the best rocket ship ever will experience some turbulence... better buckle up because it's worth the ride!
pros: Everyone has a sense of ownership and is empowered to do what they need to do. Lots of room to change roles, move around, wear as many hats as you want. The stock will almost certainly be worth something. The company has a real purpose and is generally useful/applicable/liked by real people (unlike a lot of other companies you could be working for). Getting time off is as easy as chatting with your manager - typically no questions asked. The food program is amazing with very high-quality comped breakfast/lunch/dinner. Rapid growth translates to continuous learning opportunities and a work environment that never gets boring. As an engineer - the learning opportunities never end!
cons:
Any "cons" need to be prefaced with this: remember that Square is an extremely rapidly growing company that feels like a whole new workplace every 6 months. I've tried to only list the more consistent or recurring cons here, but all of them are consistently trending positively (or I wouldn't be working here anymore, really!). Any of these cons could be gone in a month or two, or replaced with new ones. There's just no way to know!

That said:
- Immature leadership has been an ongoing theme for my entire tenure. It's been a problem at every level of leadership from executive on down at some point or another. On the other hand - I think this is to be expected of a company this age and size, and is usually course-corrected eventually.
- Immature HR (incl. compensation adjustment and talent review). First iterations of talent review were downright insulting: we were rated by shape (circle, square, or star) like kindergardeners. Luckily we acknowledged that was a horrible idea and have never done it again - but our cadence of performance feedback has remained random at best. Same goes for cadence of compensation adjustment. If you get a job here - NEGOTIATE UP FRONT - there's no telling how many months or years it might be until someone thinks to themselves "oh maybe we should look at comp again!". Note: this situation has already improved immensely with the introduction of a consistent engineering ranking/ladder system - if we manage to keep it more than a year, that is.
- Rampant politics and personal agendas. To be expected at any growing company. We have them too. Nothing special to see here, move along.
- Oncall policies. No overtime pay for brutalizing oncall shifts are the norm. No compensation for personal phone use either. Occasionally you'll get a "thank you" from someone.
- Not enough bathrooms. Not kidding. Try and find a free stall or urinal sometime after lunch. Good luck!
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing. Really. I mean it. This company is already pointed in the right direction, which means you get to spend more time thinking about how to make it go faster and bigger because you don't have to worry about steering.

review_title: I've been part of a respected, great company growing into its own.
pros:
- Believing in the company's mission and knowing that my work helps small businesses.
- Culture that respects beautiful details and design
- Growing list of products and services, many of which are unique
- Time off policy and benefits are great
cons:
- Upper management can be slow moving and risk averse
- Product development is gaining momentum, but there is a lot of catching up to do
- Limited support for internal career progression and limited empowerment of talented individuals in junior roles
advice_to_mgmt: Move quickly, take chances

pros: Exciting. Lots of opportunity for ambitious, talented engineers.
cons: Limited focus on career development -- anticipate this to improve as company matures. (The flip side is that for self-motivated engineers, there are many options.)

review_title: Great place to work with amazing co-workers
pros:
Square is a technology company that sells a "real" product. Our many many merchants depend on us to help them run and grow their businesses. When our merchants grow, we also grow with them. The incentives are perfectly aligned for us to help them do well. We don't need to sell ads based on their information, and we're not selling acorn points or whatever.

I work with incredibly talented people who have a wide range of experiences. We have a lot of fun at work, but we get our work done. Since Square has such a broad spectrum of engineering work, from hardware, to firmware, to back end services, to security, to infrastructure, to front-end (think Ember/JS/CS), to mobile (Android and iOS), there are so many opportunities to learn and to try new things.
cons: It's taken us awhile to get our product vision/road map in place, but I think we're now in a good place. We're not as extravagant with our perks as other more cash-rich tech companies, and the (free) dinner can be a bit hit or miss. The company has almost doubled while I was here, but that's simply necessary for us to grow our business.
advice_to_mgmt: We can really do better for dinner food.

review_title: Don't believe what you read in the press
pros: Square has been a fantastic experience for me. We've expanded our product from a payments solution to a full-featured point of sale, and there are lots of exciting projects happening around that. The company (and Jack) genuinely care about having a positive impact on the world.
cons: Dealing with negative press is demoralizing. Some of it's true, some of it isn't—either way, it affects recruiting candidates because they don't see what's really going on at the company.

pros:
- culture is honest and open
- colleagues are fun, hard working, and ambitious
- the work is complex, inspiring, and exciting
- leadership team is strong
- perks are perfect
- plenty of opportunities for mentorship and upward mobility
cons: - transparency efforts (ex, open Q&A each week, company-wide email threads) can make me really dislike / lose respect for some of my colleagues, but I wouldn't have it any other way honestly.

pros:
The level of transparency is shocking and inspiring. You're limited by your ambition at Square and given the data/information you need to do what you need to do.

Everyone at Square cares about what we're doing. Our mission/purpose is something worth fighting for.

Feel surrounded by the smartest people in the world.
cons: There are too few programs for learning/development/growth. The company needs to invest more in internal growth and mobility.

review_title: An entrepreneur incubator with tons of room to grow
pros:
- This stuff matters : Square is working to make it easier for the small, indie coffee shops to exist and thrive. If you want to work on stuff that matters in a real way to real people, Square is certainly going to give you that.
- Shared mission : We're working hard to make commerce easy, and everybody in the company feels this in their work.
- Fantastic leadership : The senior leadership here at Square is extraordinary. They keep us looking forward while empowering people to stand up and make big decisions that affect the future of the company.
- No ceiling : Your growth at Square is only limited by your own ambition. It's easy to move around the company and make an impact in whatever way you are able.
- Great office space : I'm a sucker for good design, and this office exemplifies that. This place embodies the agile work methodology, allowing you to easily collaborate when you need to, while giving you plenty of quiet spots to get some heads-down work done.
- Transparency : Any young entrepreneur should be chomping at the bit to work here. The opportunity to get an inside look at all of the financials and strategic decision-making at a company of this size cannot be overstated.
cons:
- Maintaining a good work-life balance is on you. There will never be a shortage of work, but there is definitely a culture of reasonable individual expectations.
- Compensation is just a touch below market, but I feel this gap is more than adequately addressed via the equity that is offered.
advice_to_mgmt:
- 401(k) matching, at this stage in the company's life, should be a given. I'm more or less baffled that this hasn't yet been addressed.
- Transparency is so important to the success that this company has enjoyed. I'd argue that the pros to keeping our transparency alive even as we grow heavily outweigh the cons of the occasional leak. This is one of the reasons I decided to work here, so please don't take it away.

review_title: Amazing opportunity for professional and personal growth
pros: Amazing environment, very talented peers, good compensation packages (equity heavy) and very rewarding work.
cons: The company is growing really fast so sometimes there is the feeling of us being stretched too thin working on too many things at the same time.
advice_to_mgmt: More clarity around what the focus should be and what projects to cut would be beneficial for the company.

pros: Square is the perfect balance between large, established company and fly-by-the-seat-of-your-pants startup. It has the culture and energy of the latter and the perks and momentum of the former. Working with this many smart, passionate, well-meaning people is a true gift.
cons: In the past things were a bit chaotic -- they still are, but we've gotten better at focus. We could still do more.
advice_to_mgmt: Letting poor performers go is hard. We need to learn to be better.

review_title: Smart people, meaningful product, fast growth
pros: Square's a great place to get your career started as a software engineer. There's a pretty high standard of code quality, good test coverage, great knowledge sharing (lots of pair programming), and it's still pretty easy to get your ideas on the table and find yourself in a position to build them out. The office is gorgeous, there are tons of perks (massage therapists & chiropractors onsite, coffee bar with baristas, cafeteria with a pizza oven for breakfast/lunch/dinner, etc), and the people are all super friendly & great to work with. The thing that really sets Square apart from others is that it both has soul as a company, and a viable business model. It's easy to see your work out in the real world, and feels validating to talk with people using the actual product.
cons: We seem to go through an inordinate amount of re-orgs, though perhaps that's normal for a company that's growing as rapidly as Square has over the last few years. With the fast growth, it's easy to slip between the cracks, so you have to keep on your toes to move with the company.
advice_to_mgmt: We put a lot of emphasis on "focus", but I'd challenge us to really think about what that means. It's difficult to focus in on product direction when the company is growing and changing at such a fast pace. We are doing too many things. Let's slow down, stop re-orging, and focus on the product.

review_title: The people - bright, sociable, kind, thoughtful. A fusion of the best of Google and Apple culture.
pros:
It's uplifting and delightful when small business owners write to us about how our software helped their business thrive by being efficient and making the right business decisions. Unlimited vacation is wonderful and opens up workplace dynamics you wouldn't see otherwise - wanna work from another city/country for a few weeks? Go right ahead, you could have taken it as vacation anyway. Need to help a friend move? Feeling tired? Take some time off.

Food is phenomenal. Perks are great. The highlight is still the people.
cons: Competition in the payments space is fierce and there are some serious 800-pound gorillas in the room (Amazon, Paypal, Apple, Google) - you don't get the comfortable security of knowing that massive network effects guarantee company success like you would at a place like Facebook, Twitter, Whatsapp, Uber, etc. There's a certain hit to morale seeing the explosive success of all these other companies while we slowly fight against the bureaucracy of governments, banks and financial systems, but I think we will outlive them all.

pros: Frontline of the best technology. Amazing work environment. Can't beat the food. perks. and location. Autonomous work setting, great for the entrepreneurial type of person. Not a place to have your hand held; take the initiative.
cons: Growing so fast - not really a con but need to be able to handle change.

pros: Great autonomy, great work life balance, learn ALOT about all sorts of different things due to the fantastic transparency of the company. Awesome office... no drudgery to a boring cubicle here!
cons: Being a small company, not much room to grow in terms of your traditional company hierarchy... but this can also be a Pro.... since as an individual you have room to run your own show and work with a small team of really smart and empowered people.

review_title: Smart people, great learning opportunity, and unique culture
pros: Smart people, great learning opportunity, and unique culture
cons: work hard culture, and need to have work time

review_title: Great, developing company with promising horizon
pros:
The organization is very flat, that being said career opportunities are everywhere. While there is not a lot of structured development, individuals are free to create their own career path and chase what interests them. This is most commonly seen in the "If its broken, than fix it" mentality that runs through the organization.

The company also has a core set of beliefs in supporting merchants and the community in a very real way. This comes to life in the product roadmaps, and the Friday ritual to spend 30 minutes cleaning the streets in our neighborhood.

The people here are great – professionals who know how to get it done.
cons:
The company is moving fast, and with any fast-paced environment there is not a lot of structure, individuals who like a comfortable and predictable day may struggle to find the 'grounding' they need to be successful.

There are some growing pains with resource allocation, and clear direction. These are usually addressed, but it can take a minute for them to surface and be prioritized.

pros:
Great culture. Lots of smart and friendly people. Solid benefits including on-site extras. Many difficult, challenging problems to work on. Lots of opportunity to grow and be part of something special with financial upside.
I read all of the Glassdoor reviews and Quora comments before joining earlier this year. You need to take them with a large grain of salt as they are limited, older data points. It's a great place if you like to work hard and enjoy delivering results that make a difference.
cons: Everybody has accepted a less than market compensation to be here. Although, Square does try to make it up with options as do many startups. Minor point - no 401k match is a bummer for savers, but again understandable given the close management of cash.
advice_to_mgmt: Maintain transparency with employees. Don't let the mistakes of the few bad apples affect the many good apples.

review_title: Awesome company with massive prospects for growth but going through some growing pains.
pros: I work with amazingly talent, super smart people every day and in all functions. The company is truly collaborative and typically doesn't let titles, roles, or politics get in the way of doing the right thing. Intense focus on the customer and taking the moral high ground even in facing of competitors who abuse and mislead their customers (unfortunately, effectively, at times).
cons: The company is going through some major growing pains. The board of directors is a superstar cast (Mary Meeker, Vinod Kohsla, Roelof Botha, Jack Dorsey, and Larry Summers) and the executive management team is very strong, especially in Products (Gokul R), Business (Francoise B), and Finance (Sarah F).
advice_to_mgmt: Spend time to build up the next level of leadership - this is the weakest area for the company. Focus more on doing fewer things, better rather than trying to many (new) things, concurrently.

pros: Highly collaborative work environment that values the ideas of it's employees. A great place to work if you want opportunities to contribute at a high level.
cons: Fast moving organization with lots of change. If you are not open to change it is not a great place for you.

pros: The company grows very fast! And everyone grows with the company together. Engineers here are very talented, and people are collaborating a lot here, so I can always learn new stuff from my peers.
cons: When a company grows really really fast, it's hard to manage the resources to make sure everyone is working on the most important thing. The company also needs to adjust the strategy, the organization to fit the changes of the market, etc.

review_title: Happy working here, have been several years, will stay
pros:
Move fairly quickly here at work. Solve interesting distributed systems problems. I've been at google, other similar startups, and other non-sfbay companies. Square is my favorite because of the real problems we are solving, the focus on design and building the right thing and helping merchants. The upside if we succeed is very big - everyone in the world does commerce daily - we want to make that better.

Worked here a long time as an engineer before trying management. Engineering managers are all engineers, which is a very good sign.
cons: Salary is lower than google, but that's what you'd expect when you trade equity for cash.

review_title: Small teams, High impact, Exciting product, Great Culture
pros: I came from Facebook, where everything was starting to feel "big company." Working at Square has been really refreshing. The environment is fast paced and there is a sense of urgency among all teams. There is autonomy to work on projects that you find interesting. Hackathon is actually Hack Week - a great time to work on whatever you find interesting. Everyone I work with is incredibly smart and I'm learning something new every day.
cons: Speaking about my team and the teams I work with, we are still working on operational efficiency. Sometimes, pulling a data set and getting set up to run analysis takes more time than it would at a mature company. But that's a trade-off I'm willing to take.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire more good leadership

pros: The company is young, smart and innovative. Everyone is passionate about the brand and what Square does. That is seen in the day to day minutiae and in large scale projects.
cons: Salary is supplemented by stellar benefits.

pros: Great environment to grow your career
cons: Compensation is lower than average.

review_title: A company with innovative products that I actually believe in!
pros: Company is growing super fast, lots of really smart and nice colleagues and (at least in my experience) very supportive management and HR teams.
cons: There are some growing pains with a company growing so big so fast. Some processes are very established while others are almost non-existent sometimes.

pros:
- Collaborative environment and culture
- Intelligent and creative co-workers
- On-site baristas, food, mac gear, massages and yoga
- Inspiring and involved CEO
cons:
- Highly inexperienced middle management
- Little to no process
- Highly political environment
- Changing culture from one that values design to solely making money

pros: Great place. Lots of young people and lots of energy. I loved working in the startup environment and not feeling restricted in what I could do. You get what you put in.
cons: Before I left things started to feel a little more corporate. They started implementing some company changes that felt a little restricting but that's probably for the best as the company grows.
advice_to_mgmt: Please maintain the strong office culture and don't change employee benefits.

pros: Great infrastructure, small teams, very obvious goals.
cons: Kind of weird, directionless management. Not a whole lot of heirarchy but it seems to be more than necessary/effectual.

pros:
Beautiful office with amazing perks and benefits.
Meaningful work and lots of ownership.
Very smart and passionate people that you get to work with.
Square succeeds when you succeed. This is a company that will listen to what you are passionate about and try to place you in a role where you will perform to at your full potential.
cons:
Salaries are not competitive, but the equity is great.
No work life balance, although I don't mind because I am very passionate about my work there.
advice_to_mgmt: Recognize your employees.

review_title: Best people I've ever worked with
pros:
Number 1: people people people. I've never worked with so many highly intelligent, friendly, curious, and intrinsically motivated people in my life. This, above all, makes going into Square every day exciting, fun, and rewarding.

- Clear mission. It's even carved into a wall in our new office. "Make commerce easy" Everyone in the company, from engineering to finance to support knows it, creating this really positive energy and spirit of teamwork like "we're all in this together."
- High impact, meaningful work. On the micro scale, it's always so cool when you visit a business running on Square and see your product being used day-in, day-out. On the macro scale, metrics showing the huge number of businesses using Square every day always awes me.
- Incredible learning opportunities. Every engineer is happy and willing to teach something new. I've learned an insane amount!
- Transparency. Almost nothing is secret inside Square. All our metrics are available to all employees. Notes from every meeting are shared - including board meetings. New strategies and products are shown early and often. A huge amount of trust is placed in each of us to keep these secrets but it's incredibly empowering and can even spark new ideas across the company.
- Challenging the status quo. Square is growing and iterating extremely fast. Old processes are quickly questioned and replaced if they get in the way. Employees are encouraged to ask the senior staff anything they want during our weekly "Town Hall" on Fridays.
- Tons of autonomy. Individually, employees have the latitude to work when they want, how they want. Some people get in past 11am & stay later while some work typical 9-5 hours. We have an unlimited vacation policy as well. Engineering teams also have a great deal of autonomy. Each team has full-stack engineers, designers, and product people so they can design, build, and ship their own product.
- Work/Life balance. I usually work around 45 hours a week and am always home for dinner. One engineer even took a whole month vacation recently. There are some who still work insane hours, but managers are actively discouraging it.
- Amazing office & perks. I love having our office downtown instead of traveling far away to some cordoned off campus. It feels like we're really a part of the city. Our restaurant in the building provides us with amazing food, but lots of food trucks and local restaurants are within blocks.
- Hack Week. 4 times a year, the entire company takes the whole week to work on something different. This isn't just for engineers - everyone participates. It brings in a lot of creative energy and has even been the birthplace of some of our products.
cons: Nothing major. Most of the cons people have written about have been addressed in the last year or so. I have no plans to leave anytime soon! :)

review_title: The best company I've worked for
pros:
Career development. My role is constantly changing (in a good way!) and I'm always learning and challenged in my work.

Hack Week. Four weeks per year that allow all employees to test and develop ideas, some of which become products (including one of mine :)

Passionate and interesting people. I'm inspired by my coworkers.

Biking to the office. I love working and living in San Francisco.
cons: A year ago, there were gaps in leadership. Most of those have been filled now with amazing leaders like Sarah Friar, Gokul Rajaram and Francoise Brougher joining the team. We're still a young company and over the past three years, I've seen lots of ups and downs. I'm feeling optimistic for the year ahead.

review_title: The most challenging and satisfying job I've ever had
pros:
Management that truly listens. A culture of constant improvement, with smart and passionate coworkers. Working on a good product at a company that cares about it's customers and community. A dynamic and quickly changing environment. A reasonable work/life balance.

Unlike some reviewers, I find the work life balance totally acceptable, but it does require require some amount of personal responsibility. Decide how much you're willing to work, and then do that. I tend to work 40 hours a week, and take several weeks of vacation a year. I encourage my team to do the same.
cons:
Square is still a young company, so it's still figuring out how best to work. There isn't always the same structure you'd expect to find at a more mature company.

We have a high standard of quality for all of our work, which can be both a pro and a con.

review_title: Fast paced workplace full of nice over achievers working really hard.
pros:
- Everyone pursues excellence.
- Everyone is masterful at their work.
- Everyone is very intelligent and many are over achievers.
- Numerous employees have founded companies previously. (Not just Jack!)
- Everyone is committed to the success of the company.
- Work is highly collaborative.
- We felt a collective swell of pride at the Starbucks deal.
- Everyone believes we're changing payments for the better.
- The work environment is an open, noise filled space. You can find a promo video on squareup.com.
- Communications are transparent across all teams. Meeting notes are available to everyone.
- The work itself is challenging, fast paced, and frequently changing.
- Leadership clearly communicates company goals and performance.
- Underperformers are let go.
- Confidential information is treated very seriously.
- The hiring bar is high and many, many candidates are interviewed and rejected.
- Teams joke around a lot, laugh a lot, and party together regularly.
- Employee retention is very high. Few people leave.
- Most people are upbeat and positive.
cons:
- Most employees work intensely for more than 10 hours a day.
- 50 to 70 hours a week is normal.
- Early stage employees tend to work very, very hard.
- There's a culture of workaholism and significant peer pressure to work until "it's done".
- Praise for an individual's good work is usually brief. The focus is on the team's success as a whole.
- There's hero worship of Square's founders.
advice_to_mgmt: Start encouraging people to rest. Your best people, especially your early employees, are repeatedly burned out. Make sure they take a proper break!

pros: Great brand equity in tech and also financial services. Some really nice people but nobody stays long. Very high quality work is produced by this company. Design is always paramount and on point. Awesome coffee.
cons:
Business practices: Square leverages its name to their advantage and to the disadvantage of everyone else. This is manifested in poor compensation for all people outside of engineering and getting out of paying for recruiting and / or sponsorship privileges for their brand. Contractors are treated as second class citizens and must be willing to work for very little pay. Full time roles are advertised as available but I know for a fact there was never headcount to begin with. All this makes the company seem disingenuous as they are constantly trying to convince people that they're the "good guys" in merchant services.

Business health: Cost cutting is apparent throughout the organization (not that this is a bad management style, but it seems to be a signal something more). Sometimes it feels like some people are shoving the proverbial company "kool-aid" down people's throats; I think anyone with a discerning eye knows what's going on.

Working environment: The company is large now so there is a lot of red tape and channel conflict. Be prepared to manoeuvre a highly political environment. Your experience largely depends on your team and manager (like every other corporate) and culture is obviously much less cohesive than at smaller companies. Tricky thing is even if you get onto a great team, I guarantee that team will not stay that way long.

Churn is very high at this company (for many reasons) so don't count on anyone sticking around for very long. 4 months in and you're considered a veteran! Most people come in and realize it's only a stepping stone.

There are lots of intelligent people here; most are not humble. There are also lots of ambitious people here but they're more likely to push you down than help you up.

Expect to work long and hard hours. Don't expect to make friends.
advice_to_mgmt: Train people managers. I was witness to some serious HR infractions carried out by managers who just didn't know better.

pros: It's great getting to work with a very talented team. I love learning something new and getting challenged each and every day. The company is incredibly transparent internally, which is really refreshing. I love building products that empower local merchants. cons: Growing fast and having many offices around the world have come with challenges. If you are the kind of person that needs to know exactly what you'll be working on in two month then Square isn't for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay agile and keep focussing on rapidly delivering innovative solutions.
